Uses of Class
prefuse.Display

  • Packages that use Display 
    Package Description
    prefuse
    The top-level Visualization and Display classes, as well as Constants used throughout the toolkit.
    prefuse.demos  
    prefuse.util
    Utility classes for use by both the toolkit and applications, including color and font support.
    prefuse.util.display
    Utility classes specific to the Display class.

    • Uses of Display in prefuse

      Methods in prefuse that return Display 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Display Visualization.getDisplay(int idx)
      Get the display at the given list index.

    • Uses of Display in prefuse.demos

      Subclasses of Display in prefuse.demos 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      class  AggregateDemo
      Demo application showcasing the use of AggregateItems to visualize groupings of nodes with in a graph visualization.
      class  DataMountain 
      class  FisheyeMenu
      A prefuse-based implementation of Fisheye Menus, showcasing the use of visual distortion to provide access to a large number of data items without scrolling.
      class  RadialGraphView
      Demonstration of a node-link tree viewer
      class  ScatterPlot
      A simple scatter plot visualization that allows visual encodings to be changed at runtime.
      class  TreeMap
      Demonstration showcasing a TreeMap layout of a hierarchical data set and the use of dynamic query binding for text search.
      class  TreeView
      Demonstration of a node-link tree viewer
      class  ZipDecode
      Re-implementation of Ben Fry's Zipdecode.
      Methods in prefuse.demos with parameters of type Display 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description

    • Uses of Display in prefuse.util

      Methods in prefuse.util with parameters of type Display 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static java.lang.String PrefuseLib.getDisplayStats(Display d)
      Returns a string showing debugging info such as number of visualized items and the current frame rate.

      Set the display view such that the given bounds are within view, subject to a given center point being maintained.
